text.p: Over the next few problems, we're going to apply the same technique of translating matrix properties to linear transformation properties, and exploiting the Fundamental Fact of Matrix Multiplication, to prove the following proposition:

Proposition. Suppose [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is an [mathjaxinline]m\times n[/mathjaxinline] matrix and [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] is an [mathjaxinline]n\times p[/mathjaxinline] matrix. If the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] are linearly independent, and the columns of [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] are linearly independent, then the columns of [mathjaxinline]AB[/mathjaxinline] are linearly independent.

Let [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] be the standard matrix for a linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline], and let [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] be the standard matrix for a linear transformation [mathjaxinline]S[/mathjaxinline]. From the assumption that the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] are linearly independent, what can we conclude about [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: We have proven that the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] are linearly independent if and only if [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is into.
